instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B orange light - no fan spin
threads.message:
First time post here - I'm relatively new at board repair in general.

As the title says, I've got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B that won't power on.  I get an orange light on the charger and no fan spin.

With a visual inspection, I found corrosion on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and components in close proximity.

I have tried quite a few things, but since I'm not even sure that I could remember all of the things I've tried so far, I'm going to just list out where things stand currently, things that I know of at least.

Voltage readings:
(In no certain order)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> at L7520 - 0.89V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R5590</RESISTOR> Pin 1 - 3.34V
L7310 - 0V

Voltage readings around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> - 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R2040</RESISTOR> - 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R2041</RESISTOR> - 1.78V

Other possibly related voltage readings:

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> - 0.80V
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R8177</RESISTOR> - 0.00V
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R8176</RESISTOR> - 0.80V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R8115</RESISTOR> - 0.00V
<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> - <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> - 0.00V



Also, in case it's relevant, the CPU gets hot.  I've tested and tried a lot of different things, but since I am new at this, please don't assume that I haven't overlooked something.
Any help and advice will be greatly appreciated!


*Edit** Reading over this again, this looks like a total plz bro type of post which wasn't my intention.  I have looked up, or at least attempted to figure out, where the missing/low lines originate and how the different rails get created.  My brain is just complete mush right now from working on this for at least 6-7 hours so far.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B orange light - no fan spin
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> - 0.80V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R2040</RESISTOR> - 3.33V"
Really strange, as <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> requires <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> to be high.
Is <CHIP>U8010</CHIP> shorted input-output?

Do you get any voltage at L7430 and L7820?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B orange light - no fan spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 65486, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> - 0.80V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R2040</RESISTOR> - 3.33V"
Really strange, as <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> requires <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> to be high.
Is <CHIP>U8010</CHIP> shorted input-output?

Do you get any voltage at L7430 and L7820?
[/QUOTE]

Thanks for the reply!

I do not get any voltage at either L7430 or L7820.

As far as <CHIP>U8010</CHIP> goes, before removing it, I probed all of the surrounding connecting components in diode mode and all gave what I would consider a normal reading.  I then went to the other nearby and possibly related/relevant mosfet's and did the same, and near <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET_R</SIGNAL> gave a very low diode mode reading, somewhere around .040, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was .025.  So I removed <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET_R</SIGNAL> now reads 0.366, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> still reads .025.   I still didn't remove <CHIP>U8010</CHIP> yet until I told you what I found with this, to see if you wanted me to go ahead and remove it for sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B orange light - no fan spin
threads.message:
0.025 is to low for <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
You said to have correct <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, so <CHIP>U8010</CHIP> should be good.
Unless is not shorted I-O.
Something else may be bad on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rail.

Please write directly on the reply box.
I don't see any reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above...
